title: Dangerous Curves/Pedestrian Hits
name: Dangerous Curves/Pedestrian Hits
description:
A Map by Madamegonzaga

Pedestrians hav ze right-ov-way! Butt ware I come from, metal eez still stronger zen flesh. So beak careful out zare und stay offa myne hit list.

L(0)(0)K both ways afore aryoooo cross ze street!

properties.name: 76-year old Joyce Lam hit by cable car and killed
properties.description: Posted by MadamegonzagaBush and Grant San Francisco CAThe problem made headlines in January when 76-year-old Joyce Lam, mother of San Francisco Superior Court Judge Newton Lam, was hit by a cable car in Chinatown and killed.

properties.name: Another Pedestrian Fatality Blamed on Sun Glare
properties.description: Posted by MadamegonzagaEl Camino del Mar and 34th Avenue, San Francisco CAKaren Kennedy, 38, who was crossing the road at the Lincoln Golf Course at El Camino del Mar near Land\'s End about 5:30 p.m. Aug. 20 when she was hit and killed by a westbound driver blinded by the sunlight.

properties.name: Beverly Kees Killed By Truck
properties.description: Posted by MadamegonzagaHarrison and Main Street, San Francisco CA"Beverly Kees, a journalism professor at San Francisco State, was killed in the crosswalk by a turning truck last December at Harrison and Main. Speakers at a vigil there six months later expressed grief and frustration that no charges had been pressed. Police standing near the vigil shrugged as cars blocked crosswalks and drivers cursed at Beverly\'s friends and neighbors trying to join the group. I doubt police would have stood idly by if raging dogs had threatened a memorial for a mauling victim." See alsooo: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/12/11/BAG70AACAG1.DTL

properties.name: Caroline Drewes, 80, beloved former Examiner reporter hit by a car as she was walking her dog.
properties.description: Posted by MadamegonzagaJackson and Lyon, San Francisco CAOn October 2, 1998, Caroline Drewes, 80, a beloved former Examiner reporter and one of the first female journalists in San Francisco to cover non-society news, was hit by a car as she was walking with her dog across Jackson Street in Pacific Heights.

properties.name: Cut off by out of town driver, totalled bike.
properties.description: Posted by Hive Polk & Eddy, SF, CAZooming down Polk, this guy decides to take a left from the right lane in his rented minivan. Bike totalled, both wrists bent up pretty badly, insurance refused to pay for any physical therapy, but did get me a swanky new bike.

properties.name: DANGEROUS INTERSECTION!
properties.description: Posted by Wendolyne This is where I saw a clueless cell-phone-talking driver hit a man on a bike who had his child in a little rumble seat behind him! Thank goodness for the new cell phone driving law, perhaps there will be some relief for the luckless pedestrian. Both child and father were unhurt but an angry mob almost lynched the urban assault vehicle\'s driver.

properties.name: Four-year-old Elizabeth Dominguez killed on the sidewalk at 24th and Potrero in 2003
properties.description: Posted by Madamegonzaga24th and Potrero, San Francisco CA"When four-year-old Elizabeth Dominguez was killed on the sidewalk at 24th and Potrero in 2003, frantic witnesses clawed the Muni truck that had crushed her against a pizza parlor. One neighbor who helped, a young man in tears, said that even after they pulled the truck back, "she stayed up there." Surely, the image of this child embedded in a wall because some driver couldn\'t be bothered to stop at the light is nightmarish enough to spark interest. Neighbors had campaigned fruitlessly for years to calm the intersection where Elizabeth was killed. Supervisor Ammiano called a special town hall meeting, but no mayoral task force followed her death."

properties.name: Nov. 17, 2000: Christopher Robertson killed on his bike in SOMA
properties.description: Posted by Madamegonzaga4th Street, San Francisco CA"On the night of Nov. 17, Christopher Robertson was riding his bicycle on 4th Street in the South of Market area of San Francisco. He was riding with 15 friends in a funeral procession for bike messenger Joseph Woods, who was shot and killed in his Mission Street apartment earlier in November. According to the traditions of S.F. bicycle messenger community, when a messenger dies, his fellows take the bike on a ceremonial ride to Mission Rock and throw it in San Francisco Bay. That night, however, Chris Robertson never made it to the water\'s edge. According to eyewitness Ron Salkin, it all happened very quickly. A tractor-trailer came up behind the procession. Enraged that the group was occupying the lane, Salkin said, the driver began weaving from one side of the road to the other, blowing his horn repeatedly. Then the driver pulled alongside the group, shouting at them. He threw a wooden block at the cyclists, trying to hit them. He swerved into the group, crushing Chris under the right front wheel of his rig, Salkin said. Robertson died."

properties.name: Pedestrian killed trying to cross I-80
properties.description: Posted by MadamegonzagaMagazine Street and I-80, Vallejo CAPedestrian killed trying to cross I-80 Peter Fimrite, Chronicle Staff Writer Thursday, June 1, 2006 (06-01) 11:15 PDT VALLEJO - A woman was struck and killed as she tried to run across Interstate 80 in Vallejo early this morning, according to the California Highway Patrol. The 46-year-old Vallejo woman was hit by a Toyota Corolla at 3 a.m. in the fast lane of westbound I-80, just west of the overhead crossing at Magazine Street. The Suisun City man driving the Corolla told officers that he was driving about 70 mph when he saw the woman and swerved to his left, but he could not avoid hitting her. The woman, whose name was not released because her relatives had not been notified, was pronounced dead at the scene. She was wearing dark clothing, the CHP said, making her less visible in the dark. CHP spokesman Willie Williford said the woman was probably trying to get to a McDonalds or 7-Eleven on the other side of the highway. "Unfortunately, it is not uncommon for people ... to make a run for it," Williford said. "It\'s light traffic at that time and they don\'t realize how fast the cars are going. People say, \'Oh that\'s a football field away.\' Well, a car travels the length of a football field in 2 seconds. I\'ve personally handled three cases where people have been hit down there." E-mail Peter Fimrite at pfimrite@sfchronicle.com.

properties.name: Walk San Francisco, your pedestrian advocacy organization
properties.description: Posted by Madamegonzaga1095 Market Street, San Francisco, CAWalk San Francisco is a member based pedestrian advocacy organization that is making San Francisco a more livable and walkable city.
